title.narrative: Partners for Resilience Global programme WI

description.narrative: Integrated Risk Management to build community resilience

PfR II will support implementation of the Sendai Framework for Action by focusing on the capacity of civil society for dialogue on integrated risk management in the domains of policy, investment and practice. Its dual strategy involves supporting partners in the global South to develop their capacity for dialogue while embarking on specific ‘trajectories’ for integrated risk management at all levels.
The alliance members will working with local implementing partners in Ethiopia, Guatemala, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Mali, Haiti, Philippines, South Sudan and Uganda – covering more than 500 communities and engaging with well over 200 government institutions

The new partnership will build the capacity of civil society in its focus countries to influence policy-making, investments and practice on integrated risk management at the local, national, regional and global level.
Partners for Resilience will help local groups engage with the development and implementation of policies, legislative frameworks, investment and funding, inclusive processes and linking up with practice at community level.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 471 6700 AL Wageningen The Netherlands

title.narrative: Level of inclusion of Integrated Risk Management principles in investments (0-5)

comment.narrative: 03-07-2018: We are mostly working on awareness raising on IRM, e.g. on de-risk planned and existing investments such as infrastructure, dams, barrages, irrigation schemes etc. and also on investments in Green or Blue Infrastructure solutions. Some countries show that they are supportive, for example through NDC's, which PfR has been actively advocating for. Building with Nature (e.g. Indonesia case) is being used frequently as a learning case internationally, including in publications for water practitioners and for engineers and port developers. In the EU we are targeting EU investments, in particular for the Sahelian region, which is receiving a lot of attention. RCCC is in the lead of influencing climate finance, so they can judge ambitions and progress on this better than WI.

10-01-2018: In June 2016, OCHA and UNEP accepted PfR in the Environment and Humanitarian Action Network. And commissioned a research to their partner London School of Economics to collect evidence about the importance of risk informed investments. The research is expected to be ready by April 2017 with PfR being given the role of Research Project Coordinator. The DRR community focused on ecosystem-based solutions and engineering communities were brought together to establish a dialogue on how to better promote Eco-DRR approaches in the context of disaster risk management as well as resilient development planning. Golden rules and principles were embraced by all participants. The outcomes of the dialogue are basis for a workshop in April 2017 organised by World Bank/UNDP, Deltares and Ecoshape on scaling up nature based solutions for flood defences World Business Council on sustainable development asked PfR-partner WI to develop modules for their course ‘Natural Infrastructure for Business’, which promotes increased investments in nature-based solutions that are good to business, society and the environment GFDRR disaster risk financing initiative integrated early action in its disaster risk financing cycle (World Bank) investment financing can now structurally include elements of early action)

27-06-2019: Effective engagement in the SDG dialogues at global level to develop a strong narrative on PfR’s contribution to the SDG agenda. We devised a strategy that enabled the Mali team to engage the Mali Government and advocate for the inclusion of civil society in Mali to contribute to the Mali Voluntary National Review Report (VNR) which was presented at the High-Level Political Forum in New York. PfR, through Mali Red Cross, was invited to be part of the Mali Delegation, preparing the position paper and highlighting key issues, among others, security concerns impacting the implementation of SDGs, and the issue of land degradation which also exacerbates poverty. The Mali engagement in the VNR process sparked interest from the International Federation of the Red Cross in New York to use their (Mali’s) engagement process as learning for more Red Cross-National Societies to engage on SDGs.
DD4: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
